TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit PropertyGrid extends System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl implements class System.Windows.Forms.ComponentModel.Com2Interop.IComPropertyBrowser

Docs.summary: Provides a user interface for browsing the properties of an object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks To use the property grid, you create a new instance of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> class on a parent control and set <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.SelectedObject%2A> to the object to display the properties for.
The information displayed in the grid is a snapshot of the properties at the time the object is assigned. If a property value of the object specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.SelectedObject%2A> is changed in code at run time, the new value is not displayed until an action is taken in the grid that causes the grid to refresh.
The property tabs within the property grid appear as buttons on the toolbar at the top of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid>, and can vary in scope as defined in the <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyTabScope>.
You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.LargeButtons%2A> property to display large buttons instead of the default smaller ones. Large buttons are 32-by-32 pixels rather than the standard 16-by-16 pixels. The large and small buttons and the property list expander icons (the plus or minus icons) are resized according to the system DPI setting when the app.config file contains the following entry:
``` <appSettings> <add key="EnableWindowsFormsHighDpiAutoResizing" value="true" /> </appSettings>
```
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> control is not initially presented in the toolbox in the development environment. You can add a property grid to the toolbox, which enables you to drag a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> onto your form. You can also define an instance of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> by adding the appropriate code in your source code.
All public properties of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.SelectedObject%2A> will be displayed in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> by default. You can hide a property so that it is not displayed in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> control by decorating it with the <xref:System.ComponentModel.BrowsableAttribute> and setting the value to `false`. You can specify the category that a property appears in by providing a category with the <xref:System.ComponentModel.CategoryAttribute>. You can provide descriptive text for your property that appears at the bottom of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> control by using the <xref:System.ComponentModel.DescriptionAttribute>.
## Examples The following code example illustrates creating a property grid and setting its location on a form. This example requires that you have a form with a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> on it.
[!code-cpp[Classic PropertyGrid Example#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic PropertyGrid Example/CPP/source.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[Classic PropertyGrid Example#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic PropertyGrid Example/CS/source.cs#1)] [!code-vb[Classic PropertyGrid Example#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/Classic PropertyGrid Example/VB/source.vb#1)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the browsable attributes associated with the object that the property grid is attached to.
Docs.value: The collection of browsable attributes associated with the object.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Only properties with attributes matching the values specified are displayed in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid>. The default is an <xref:System.ComponentModel.AttributeCollection> containing only <xref:System.ComponentModel.BrowsableAttribute.Yes?displayProperty=fullName>.
Assigning an attribute collection that is empty or is `null` causes a new <xref:System.ComponentModel.AttributeCollection> to be created with <xref:System.ComponentModel.BrowsableAttribute.Yes?displayProperty=fullName> set.

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the commands pane can be made visible for the currently selected objects.
Docs.value: if the commands pane can be made visible; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property is `true` if <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.CommandsVisibleIfAvailable%2A> is `true` and the object has commands available.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether OS-specific visual style glyphs are used for the expansion nodes in the grid area.
Docs.value: to use the visual style glyphs; otherwise, .

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the text color used for category headings.
Docs.value: A structure representing the text color.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The background color of category headings is determined by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.LineColor%2A> property.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the color of the line that separates categories in the grid area.
Docs.value: The color of the category splitter.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void CollapseAllGridItems() cil managed

Docs.summary: Collapses all the categories in the .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The method collapses the categories in the grid. Those categories that have grid items in the category have a plus sign (+) displayed next to that category.

remarks.format: ## Remarks This property is `true` if the selected object has commands available and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.CommandsVisibleIfAvailable%2A> property is `true`.

Docs.summary: Gets the default location for the shortcut menu.
Docs.value: The default location for the shortcut menu if the command is invoked. Typically, this is centered over the selected property.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The shortcut menu location is the center of the active property label in the grid. You can use this information to position the shortcut menu when the menu is invoked using the keyboard.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig virtual instance void Dispose(bool disposing) cil managed

Docs.param: to release both managed and unmanaged resources; to release only unmanaged resources.
Docs.summary: Disposes of the resources (other than memory) used by the .

remarks.format:
## Remarks Call <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.Dispose%2A> when you are finished using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid>. The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.Dispose%2A> method leaves the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> in an unusable state. After calling <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.Dispose%2A>, you must release all references to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> so the memory it was occupying can be reclaimed by garbage collection.
> [!NOTE] > Always call <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.Dispose%2A> before you release your last reference to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid>. Otherwise, the resources the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> is using will not be freed until garbage collection calls the destructor of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid>.

Docs.summary: Occurs when a key is first pressed.

remarks.format:
## Remarks For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
## Examples The following code example demonstrates the use of this member. In the example, an event handler reports on the occurrence of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.KeyDown> event. This report helps you to learn when the event occurs and can assist you in debugging. To report on multiple events or on events that occur frequently, consider replacing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MessageBox.Show%2A?displayProperty=fullName> with <xref:System.Console.WriteLine%2A?displayProperty=fullName> or appending the message to a multiline <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox>.
To run the example code, paste it into a project that contains an instance of type <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> named `PropertyGrid1`. Then ensure that the event handler is associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.KeyDown> event.
[!code-csharp[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#522](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/CS/EventExamples.cs#522)] [!code-vb[System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples#522](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/System.Windows.Forms.EventExamples/VB/EventExamples.vb#522)]

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether buttons appear in standard size or in large size.
Docs.value: if buttons on the control appear large; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use this property to enhance accessibility. Large buttons are 32-by-32 pixels rather than the standard 16-by-16 pixels. Both the large and small buttons are resized according to the system DPI setting when the app.config file contains the following entry:
``` <appSettings> <add key="EnableWindowsFormsHighDpiAutoResizing" value="true" /> </appSettings>
```

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the color of the gridlines and borders.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is the default system color for scroll bars.

MemberSignature.Value: .method familyhidebysig instance void OnComComponentNameChanged(class System.ComponentModel.Design.ComponentRenameEventArgs e) cil managed

Docs.param: A that contains the event data.
Docs.summary: Raises the event.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.OnComComponentNameChanged%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's method so that registered delegates receive the event.

## Remarks Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.OnSelectedGridItemChanged%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.

block.para: When overriding in a derived class, be sure to call the base classs method so that registered delegates receive the event.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the type of sorting the uses to display properties.
Docs.value: One of the values. The default is or .

remarks.format:
## Remarks When you set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.PropertySort%2A> property, the appearance of the property sort buttons on the grid changes to reflect the current state of the property. Setting <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.PropertySort%2A> to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertySort?displayProperty=fullName> causes the properties to be displayed in the order they were retrieved.
Setting <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.PropertySort%2A> to both <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertySort.Alphabetical> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertySort.Categorized> is the same as setting <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.PropertySort%2A> to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertySort.Categorized> alone. The categorized view is always shown as alphabetical.
> [!NOTE] > To do custom sorting, implement <xref:System.ComponentModel.ICustomTypeDescriptor> on the component to return the properties in the desired order.
## Examples The following code example demonstrates initializing a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> control using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.PropertySort%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.ToolbarVisible%2A> properties. In addition, this example sets the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> control's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Visible%2A> property to `false` so the grid will not be visible when the example is run. To run this example paste the following code in a form and call the `InitializePropertyGrid` method from the form's constructor or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form.Load> event-handling method. To view the property grid when the form is running, change the grid's <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Visible%2A> property to `true`, recompile, and rerun the form.

Docs.exception: The assigned value is not one of the values.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the object for which the grid displays properties.
Docs.value: The first object in the object list. If there is no currently selected object the return is .

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.SelectedObject%2A> property sets a single object into the grid to be browsed. If multiple objects are being browsed, this property returns the first one in the list. If no objects are selected, `null` is returned.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the currently selected objects.
Docs.value: An array of type . The default is an empty array.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> only displays the properties that are common to all the objects that are in the array. Assigning an array to the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.SelectedObjects%2A> replaces the reference to any <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.SelectedObject%2A> you might make.

Docs.exception: One of the items in the array of objects had a null value.

Docs.summary: Occurs when the objects selected by the property have changed.

## Remarks This member is an explicit interface member implementation. It can be used only when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ComponentModel.Com2Interop.IComPropertyBrowser> interface.
[!INCLUDE[vsprvslong](~/includes/vsprvslong-md.md)] saves some of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid> control states, such as the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.PropertySort%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PropertyGrid.HelpVisible%2A> properties, to the registry and loads them the next time the user runs the application.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the painting functionality for objects.
Docs.value: A for the .

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines whether to use the class ([!INCLUDE[ndptecgdiplus](~/includes/ndptecgdiplus-md.md)]) or the class ([!INCLUDE[ndptecgdi](~/includes/ndptecgdi-md.md)]) to render text.
Docs.value: if the class should be used to perform text rendering for compatibility with versions 1.0 and 1.1. of the .NET Framework; otherwise, . The default is .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The `UseCompatibleTextRendering` property is intended to provide visual compatibility between Windows Forms controls that render text using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextRenderer> class and [!INCLUDE[net_v10_short](~/includes/net-v10-short-md.md)] and [!INCLUDE[net_v11_short](~/includes/net-v11-short-md.md)] applications that perform custom text rendering using the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> class. In most cases, if your application is not being upgraded from [!INCLUDE[net_v10_short](~/includes/net-v10-short-md.md)] or [!INCLUDE[net_v11_short](~/includes/net-v11-short-md.md)], it is recommended that you leave `UseCompatibleTextRendering` set to the default value of `false`.
The [!INCLUDE[ndptecgdi](~/includes/ndptecgdi-md.md)] based <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextRenderer> class was introduced in the [!INCLUDE[dnprdnlong](~/includes/dnprdnlong-md.md)] to improve performance, make text look better, and improve support for international fonts. In earlier versions of the [!INCLUDE[dnprdnshort](~/includes/dnprdnshort-md.md)], the [!INCLUDE[ndptecgdiplus](~/includes/ndptecgdiplus-md.md)] based <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> class was used to perform all text rendering. [!INCLUDE[ndptecgdi](~/includes/ndptecgdi-md.md)] calculates character spacing and word wrapping differently from [!INCLUDE[ndptecgdiplus](~/includes/ndptecgdiplus-md.md)]. In a Windows Forms application that uses the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> class to render text, this could cause the text for controls that use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextRenderer> to appear different from the other text in the application. To resolve this incompatibility, you can set the `UseCompatibleTextRendering` property to `true` for a specific control. To set `UseCompatibleTextRendering` to `true` for all supported controls in the application, call the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Application.SetCompatibleTextRenderingDefault%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method with a parameter of `true`.
